history.content:
In my experience, it makes more sense to take EE/CS 375 during the first semester of your TA-ship. There's self-reflections after every discussion or lab section that really only make sense if you're already teaching a section.

A class that you might be interested is "CS 370", or Intro to Teaching Computer Science. This course is geared more towards current lab assistants and tutors who are aspiring to become TA's although it can also be taken by TA's as well.

The course is currently set for graduate student enrollment only.  The department will absolutely give access to undergrads who are TAing in F16 (and perhaps for a different as of yet unscheduled section for TAs who are first time instructors in SU16) but before we open it to people who are not TA-ing in F16, we have to make sure we can accommodate everyone who will be TAing at that time and is required to take the course.

As the student answer describes above, the course is organized around the assumption that people taking the course are in fact teaching a section in that same semester.  (Note: CS 370 does not exist.  There is a decal that a former student decided to call CS 370 but the creation of new courses is something only the faculty --through their democratic governing bodies -- can do and neither staff nor students are able to do so even if and when we have really nifty ideas. It is possible at some point such a CS370 will exist.)

I want to eventually become a TA, so I tried to enroll in one of these courses and got an error message about course content. I tried the other and the same happened. How do you get enrolled in one of theses courses?
history.subject: Enrolling in EE/CS 375
